faqs.What are antenatal tests?: Antenatal tests are conducted during pregnancy to monitor the health of the pregnant person and foetus.
faqs.Why are antenatal tests conducted?: For identifying potential complications early to ensure appropriate interventions and a healthy pregnancy and delivery.
faqs.Who should get this test done?: All pregnant individuals should get antenatal tests to monitor their health and the developing foetus’s well-being.
faqs.Why are these tests important?: These tests ensure a safe, healthy pregnancy by identifying potential issues early. Protect your health and your baby’s well-being, allowing you to enjoy the excitement of welcoming your new addition. Trust these comprehensive tests for a smooth pregnancy journey.

test_included.CBC: Complete Blood Count (CBC) measures red and white blood cells, haemoglobin, and platelets to detect anaemia and infections, crucial for monitoring maternal and foetal health.
test_included.Blood Group: Blood Group testing determines maternal blood type and Rh factor, essential for managing Rh compatibility and transfusion needs during pregnancy.
test_included.Glucose (F/ PR/ R/ PG): Glucose tests (Fasting, Postprandial, Random, Post Glucose) monitor blood sugar levels to detect and manage gestational diabetes.
test_included.TSH Ultra: Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH) Ultra test checks thyroid function, vital for maintaining maternal metabolism and supporting foetal development.
test_included.Urine Routine: Urine Routine analysis screens for urinary tract infections and kidney issues, ensuring a healthy pregnancy by detecting potential complications early.
test_included.VDRL: VDRL test screens for syphilis, preventing serious pregnancy complications and ensuring timely treatment to protect maternal and foetal health.
test_included.ELISA: ELISA test detects antibodies for infections and autoimmune conditions, crucial for early intervention and maintaining a healthy pregnancy.
test_included.Serology (HIV, HBSAG, HCV): Serology tests for HIV, Hepatitis B (HBSAG), and Hepatitis C (HCV) identify viral infections, essential for preventing transmission and managing maternal health.

faqs.What is the Diabetes Monitoring Panel?: Tests for blood glucose levels, kidney function, cholesterol, and urine microalbumin.
faqs.Why are these tests conducted?: To monitor diabetes management and assess kidney and cardiovascular health.
faqs.Who should get this test done?: Individuals with diabetes or those at risk of developing diabetes.
faqs.Why are these tests important?: They help track blood sugar control and detect complications early, ensuring effective diabetes management.

test_included.Blood Group: Blood Group testing determines maternal blood type and Rh factor, essential for managing Rh compatibility and transfusion needs during pregnancy.

test_included.TSH Ultra: Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone (TSH) Ultra test checks thyroid function, vital for maintaining maternal metabolism and supporting foetal development.
test_included.Urine Routine: Urine Routine analysis screens for urinary tract infections and kidney issues, ensuring a healthy pregnancy by detecting potential complications early.
test_included.VDRL: VDRL test screens for syphilis, preventing serious pregnancy complications and ensuring timely treatment to protect maternal and foetal health.

testDescriptions.CBC: Complete Blood Count (CBC) measures various components of blood to detect anemia and signs of inflammation, which are crucial for assessing overall health in arthritis patients.
testDescriptions.ESR: Erythrocyte Sedimentation Rate (ESR) measures the rate at which red blood cells settle in a tube over a specific period. Elevated rates indicate inflammation, helping diagnose and monitor arthritis and its severity.
testDescriptions.SGPT: SGPT (ALT) is a liver enzyme test that assesses liver function. Monitoring SGPT levels is important to ensure that liver function remains stable, especially during arthritis treatment.
testDescriptions.SGOT: SGOT (AST) is another liver enzyme test that evaluates liver function and helps monitor potential liver damage, which can be a side effect of arthritis medications.
testDescriptions.Urea: The Urea test measures kidney function by evaluating the concentration of urea in the blood. This is important as certain arthritis treatments can impact kidney function.
testDescriptions.Uric Acid: The Uric Acid test checks for elevated levels of uric acid in the blood, which can indicate gout, a type of arthritis characterized by sudden and severe pain and inflammation.
testDescriptions.CRP: C-Reactive Protein (CRP) measures the level of CRP in the blood, which increases in response to inflammation. This test helps in diagnosing and monitoring inflammatory arthritis conditions.
testDescriptions.RA Factor: Rheumatoid Factor (RA Factor) is a test that detects antibodies associated with rheumatoid arthritis. It aids in the diagnosis and monitoring of rheumatoid arthritis.
testDescriptions.ANA: Antinuclear Antibody (ANA) test screens for autoimmune disorders, such as lupus, which can present with arthritis-like symptoms and affect joint health.
testDescriptions.Urine Routine: Urine Routine analysis examines urine for abnormalities, helping detect kidney issues or infections, which can be complications of arthritis or its treatments.

faqs.purpose: To diagnose different types of arthritis, monitor levels of inflammation, and evaluate liver and kidney function, which can be affected by arthritis or its treatments.
faqs.importance: These tests provide a comprehensive view of inflammation, joint health, liver and kidney function, and help guide effective treatment and management of arthritis.
faqs.whoShouldGetTested: Individuals experiencing joint pain, swelling, or stiffness, or those who suspect they might have arthritis, should consider this panel. It is also useful for monitoring existing arthritis conditions.
